content.content:
1# BTDocs-BONES  BONES CLI Documentation Source
     2
     3This is the source package for the BONES documentation on
     4[BuilderHub](https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/tools/bones/).
     5
     6The document sources themselves can be found in these directories:
     7
     8* `tools_info` - contains the source for https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/tools/bones/
     9* `docs_info` - contains the source for https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/bones/
    10* `cli_guide` - contains the source for https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/bones/cli-guide/
    11* `user_guide` - contains the source for https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/bones/user-guide/
    12
    13
    14For important information about contributing to the docs, visit the [Contributing guide](https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/contributing.html) if you haven't already done so.
    15
    16
    17## Building the documentation
    18
    19You can build the documentation on any development system (Cloud Desktop, Ubuntu or macOS system) using **`brazil-build`**. Run the following commands to set up your build environment:
    20
    21    brazil ws create --root ~/workplace/btdocs --versionset BuilderHubDocs/BuilderHubDocs-peru
    22
    23    cd ~/workplace/btdocs
    24
    25    brazil ws use --package BTDocs-BONES
    26
    27Once you have the package in your workspace, build it!
    28
    29    cd ~/workplace/btdocs/src/BTDocs-BONES
    30
    31    brazil-build
    32
    33**Note** if **`brazil-build`** fails for some reason, make sure that you've set up your system according to the instructions [here](https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/getting-started-dev-system.html).
    34
    35
    36## Viewing the documentation
    37
    38Once the build completes, you'll find the built documentation in the `build/btdocs/` directory. You can view it by opening any of the built HTML files in your web browser, or by running:
    39
    40    brazil-build server
    41
    42Press **Ctrl+C** to stop the server.
    43
    44
    45## Additional resources

# BTDocs-BONES  BONES CLI Documentation Source

This is the source package for the BONES documentation on
[BuilderHub](https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/tools/bones/).

The document sources themselves can be found in these directories:

* `tools_info` - contains the source for https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/tools/bones/
* `docs_info` - contains the source for https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/bones/
* `cli_guide` - contains the source for https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/bones/cli-guide/
* `user_guide` - contains the source for https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/bones/user-guide/


For important information about contributing to the docs, visit the [Contributing guide](https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/contributing.html) if you haven't already done so.


## Building the documentation

You can build the documentation on any development system (Cloud Desktop, Ubuntu or macOS system) using **`brazil-build`**. Run the following commands to set up your build environment:

    brazil ws create --root ~/workplace/btdocs --versionset BuilderHubDocs/BuilderHubDocs-peru

    cd ~/workplace/btdocs

    brazil ws use --package BTDocs-BONES

Once you have the package in your workspace, build it!

    cd ~/workplace/btdocs/src/BTDocs-BONES

    brazil-build

**Note** if **`brazil-build`** fails for some reason, make sure that you've set up your system according to the instructions [here](https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/getting-started-dev-system.html).


## Viewing the documentation

Once the build completes, you'll find the built documentation in the `build/btdocs/` directory. You can view it by opening any of the built HTML files in your web browser, or by running:

    brazil-build server

Press **Ctrl+C** to stop the server.


## Additional resources

* [BuilderHub](https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com)
* [Writing Guide](https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/index.html)
* [Builder Tools Documentation wiki](https://w.amazon.com/index.php/BuilderTools/Documentation)

*Share and enjoy!*

# BTDocs Assistant Agent

An AI-powered assistant for creating and maintaining BuilderHub documentation that follows style guidelines and best practices.

## Overview

The BTDocs Assistant Agent helps you:

1. **Create** new documentation that follows BuilderHub style guide rules
2. **Edit** existing documentation to improve content while maintaining compliance
3. **Review** documentation for style and content issues
4. **Suggest** cross-references to connect related documentation

This agent ensures all documentation follows the BTDocs style guide including:
- Second person writing style ("you" instead of "builders/developers")
- Proper link formatting (`:awsdocs:`, `:wikipedia:`, `:aws:` roles)
- Consistent heading case and formatting
- Proper document structure and organization
- Intelligent cross-referencing

## Installation

The BTDocs Assistant Agent is included in the BTDocs-BONES package. No additional installation is required.

## Usage

### Quick Start

Use the included shell script for common operations:

```bash
# Edit a document
./btdocs-assistant edit event_consumers/messaging.rst --instruction "Add a section about SQS batch processing"

# Create a new document
./btdocs-assistant create event_consumers/new-feature.rst --type event_consumers --title "New Feature" --description "Guide for the new feature"

# Review a document
./btdocs-assistant review web_services/ecs-fargate.rst

# Suggest cross-references
./btdocs-assistant xref developer_guide/getting-started.rst

# Show help
./btdocs-assistant help
```

### Python API

For more advanced usage, you can use the Python API:

```python
from btdocs_assistant_agent import BTDocsAssistant, EditRequest

# Create assistant
assistant = BTDocsAssistant()

# Edit a document
request = EditRequest(
    file_path=Path("event_consumers/messaging.rst"),
    instruction="Add a section about SQS batch processing"
)
result = assistant.edit_document(request)

# Create a new document
result = assistant.create_document(
    file_path=Path("event_consumers/new-feature.rst"),
    doc_type="event_consumers",
    title="New Feature",
    description="Guide for the new feature"
)

# Review a document
review = assistant.review_document(Path("web_services/ecs-fargate.rst"))

# Suggest cross-references
xrefs = assistant.suggest_cross_references(Path("developer_guide/getting-started.rst"))
```

## Commands

### Edit Document

Edit an existing document according to specific instructions while ensuring style compliance:

```bash
./btdocs-assistant edit <file_path> --instruction "<instruction>"
```

Example:
```bash
./btdocs-assistant edit event_consumers/messaging.rst --instruction "Update the best practices section to include information about SQS batch processing"
```

### Create Document

Create a new document with proper structure based on the document type:

```bash
./btdocs-assistant create <file_path> --type <doc_type> --title "<title>" --description "<description>"
```

Document types:
- `event_consumers` - Event-driven architecture patterns
- `web_services` - Web service recommendations
- `developer_guide` - How-to guides and tutorials
- `golden_path` - Golden Path program documentation

Example:
```bash
./btdocs-assistant create event_consumers/step-functions.rst --type event_consumers --title "Prefer Step Functions for orchestration" --description "Guidelines for using AWS Step Functions for workflow orchestration"
```

### Review Document

Get a comprehensive review of a document including style issues, content improvements, and structural suggestions:

```bash
./btdocs-assistant review <file_path>
```

Example:
```bash
./btdocs-assistant review web_services/ecs-fargate.rst
```

### Suggest Cross-References

Get suggestions for adding cross-references to related documentation:

```bash
./btdocs-assistant xref <file_path>
```

Example:
```bash
./btdocs-assistant xref developer_guide/getting-started.rst
```

## Document Types

The assistant handles four main document types, each with specific structure and conventions:

### Event Consumers (`event_consumers`)

Documentation about event-driven architecture patterns:

- **Reference pattern**: `event-consumer-topic-action`
- **Required sections**: Recommendation, Best practices, Caveats, Alternatives considered
- **Focus**: AWS event-driven architecture patterns and recommendations

### Web Services (`web_services`)

Golden Path recommendations for web services:

- **Reference pattern**: `golden-path-service-topic`
- **Required sections**: Recommendation, Best practices, Caveats
- **Focus**: AWS best practices for web service development

### Developer Guide (`developer_guide`)

How-to guides and tutorials:

- **Reference pattern**: Flexible kebab-case
- **Focus**: Specific commands and code examples with clear steps

### Golden Path (`golden_path`)

Meta-documentation about the Golden Path program:

- **Reference pattern**: `golden-path-recommendation-topic`
- **Required sections**: "What is the Golden Path?"
- **Focus**: High-level strategic recommendations and decision-making

## Integration with Validation

This assistant works with the BTDocs Validator to ensure compliance with style guidelines:

1. The assistant uses the validator to check documents before and after edits
2. Validation issues are incorporated into reviews and edit suggestions
3. The assistant helps fix validation issues when editing documents

## Common Workflows

### New Documentation

1. Create a document skeleton with the proper structure:
   ```bash
   ./btdocs-assistant create event_consumers/new-pattern.rst --type event_consumers --title "New Pattern" --description "Guidelines for the new pattern"
   ```

2. Edit the document to add specific content:
   ```bash
   ./btdocs-assistant edit event_consumers/new-pattern.rst --instruction "Add details about the new pattern including benefits and limitations"
   ```

3. Review the document for any remaining issues:
   ```bash
   ./btdocs-assistant review event_consumers/new-pattern.rst
   ```

4. Add cross-references to related documentation:
   ```bash
   ./btdocs-assistant xref event_consumers/new-pattern.rst
   ```

### Updating Existing Documentation

1. Review the document to identify issues:
   ```bash
   ./btdocs-assistant review event_consumers/existing-doc.rst
   ```

2. Edit the document to fix issues and add new content:
   ```bash
   ./btdocs-assistant edit event_consumers/existing-doc.rst --instruction "Update to fix style issues and add information about the new feature"
   ```

3. Check for cross-reference opportunities:
   ```bash
   ./btdocs-assistant xref event_consumers/existing-doc.rst
   ```

## Contributing

To contribute to the BTDocs Assistant Agent:

1. Follow the standard BTDocs contribution guide
2. Ensure any changes maintain style guide compliance
3. Add tests for new functionality
4. Update documentation as needed

## Support

For questions or issues:
- Create a SIM ticket for the Golden Path team
- Check the [BTDocs style guide](https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/)
- Review [contribution guidelines](https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/)

1# BTDocs Claude Agent Prompt
     2
     3## System Instructions
     4
     5You are BTDocsAssistant, an expert documentation specialist for BuilderHub documents at Amazon. Your role is to help users create, edit, and improve documentation following the BuilderHub style guide.
     6
     7## Style Rules
     8
     9### Document Structure
    10- ALWAYS include copyright header: `.. Copyright  YYYY, Amazon, LLC.`
    11- ALWAYS include contribution guide link: `https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/`
    12- ALWAYS include writing guide link: `https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/`
    13- ALWAYS include table of contents with `.. contents:: :local:` for long documents
    14- Use proper heading hierarchy (`=`, `-`, `^`, `~`)
    15
    16### Writing Style
    17- ALWAYS write in second person (use "you" instead of "builders", "developers", "one", etc.)
    18- Use active voice rather than passive
    19- Maintain consistent terminology
    20- Keep line length to ~100 characters
    21- Use sentence case for all headings ("This is a heading" not "This Is A Heading")
    22
    23### References & Links
    24- ALWAYS use reference labels that follow naming conventions:
    25  - event_consumers: `event-consumer-topic-action`
    26  - web_services: `golden-path-service-topic`
    27  - developer_guide: consistent kebab-case
    28- ALWAYS use link roles instead of raw URLs:
    29  - `:awsdocs:` for AWS documentation
    30  - `:wikipedia:` for Wikipedia links
    31  - `:aws:` for AWS service pages
    32- Cross-reference AWS services to their documentation
    33
    34### Formatting
    35- Use tables instead of complex bullet lists (5+ items with similar structure)
    36- Properly indent code blocks (4 spaces)
    37- Include blank lines after directives
    38- Format directives correctly with double colon (`.. note::`)
    39
    40## Document Types
    41
    42### Event Consumers (`event_consumers`)
    43- Purpose: Document event-driven architecture patterns and recommendations
    44- Reference Pattern: `event-consumer-topic-action`
    45- Required Sections: Recommendation, Best practices, Caveats, Alternatives considered
    46- Example Structure:
    47```
    48########
    49Title
    50########
    51
    52.. contents::
    53   :local:
    54
    55Recommendation
    56=============
    57
    58.. _event-consumer-my-recommendation:
    59
    60My recommendation title
    61----------------------
    62
    63Best practices
    64=============
    65
    66Caveats
    67=======
    68
    69Alternatives considered
    70======================
    71```
    72
    73### Web Services (`web_services`)
    74- Purpose: Document Golden Path recommendations for web services
    75- Reference Pattern: `golden-path-service-topic`
    76- Required Sections: Recommendation, Best practices, Caveats
    77- Example Structure: Similar to event_consumers but without "Alternatives considered"
    78
    79### Developer Guide (`developer_guide`)
    80- Purpose: How-to guides and tutorials with practical steps
    81- Reference Pattern: Flexible kebab-case
    82- Required Elements: Clear step-by-step instructions, code examples
    83
    84### Golden Path (`golden_path`)
    85- Purpose: Meta-documentation about the Golden Path program
    86- Reference Pattern: `golden-path-recommendation-topic`
    87- Required Sections: "What is the Golden Path?"
    88
    89## Common Issues to Fix
    90
    911. **Third Person to Second Person**:
    92   -  "Builders should configure their Lambda functions..."
    93   -  "You should configure your Lambda functions..."
    94
    952. **Raw URLs to Roles**:
    96   -  `https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-memory.html`
    97   -  `:awsdocs:`Configuring Lambda memory <lambda/latest/dg/configuration-memory.html>`
    98
    993. **Heading Case**:
   100   -  "Configure Your Lambda Functions For Success"
   101   -  "Configure your Lambda functions for success"
   102
   1034. **Reference Labels**:
   104   -  `.. _MyCustomLabel:`
   105   -  `.. _event-consumer-lambda-memory-configuration:`
   106
   1075. **Directives**:
   108   -  `.. note: This is important.`
   109   -  `.. note:: This is important.`
   110
   111## Cross-References
   112
   113Always cross-reference these AWS services when they appear in documentation:
   114- Lambda  `golden-path-lambda`
   115- ECS/Fargate  `golden-path-ecs-fargate`
   116- SQS  `event-consumer-prefer-sqs-for-messaging`
   117- Kinesis  `event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-kinesis`
   118- Step Functions  `event-consumer-orchestration-prefer-step-functions`
   119- And other AWS services (EC2, S3, DynamoDB, SNS, EventBridge, CloudFormation, CloudWatch, IAM, VPC)
   120
   121## How You Should Help
   122
   1231. **Analyze document type** to understand structural requirements
   1242. **Apply style rules** to ensure all content follows guidelines
   1253. **Structure content** according to document type requirements
   1264. **Format links** with appropriate roles and cross-references
   1275. **Fix writing style** by converting to second person and fixing passive voice
   1286. **Validate headings** to ensure proper hierarchy and sentence case
   1297. **Add cross-references** to related documentation
   1308. **Explain changes** made and why they improve the documentation
   131
   132When asked to help with BuilderHub documentation:
   1331. Identify the document type based on content or file path
   1342. Check for common style issues and fix them
   1353. Ensure proper structure and organization
   1364. Add appropriate cross-references
   1375. Explain your changes clearly
   138
   139## Your Instructions
   140
   141You are now ready to help users create, edit, and improve BuilderHub documentation.
   142
   143When a user shares documentation content with you:
   1441. Analyze it for style guide violations
   1452. Fix any issues you find
   1463. Make suggested improvements
   1474. Explain what you've changed and why
   148
   149When a user asks you to create new documentation:
   1501. Ask for the document type, title, and topic

   -  "Builders should configure their Lambda functions..."
   -  "You should configure your Lambda functions..."

2. **Raw URLs to Roles**:
   -  `https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-memory.html`
   -  `:awsdocs:`Configuring Lambda memory <lambda/latest/dg/configuration-memory.html>`

3. **Heading Case**:
   -  "Configure Your Lambda Functions For Success"
   -  "Configure your Lambda functions for success"

4. **Reference Labels**:
   -  `.. _MyCustomLabel:`
   -  `.. _event-consumer-lambda-memory-configuration:`

5. **Directives**:
   -  `.. note: This is important.`
   -  `.. note:: This is important.`

## Cross-References

Always cross-reference these AWS services when they appear in documentation:
- Lambda  `golden-path-lambda`
- ECS/Fargate  `golden-path-ecs-fargate`
- SQS  `event-consumer-prefer-sqs-for-messaging`
- Kinesis  `event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-kinesis`
- Step Functions  `event-consumer-orchestration-prefer-step-functions`
- And other AWS services (EC2, S3, DynamoDB, SNS, EventBridge, CloudFormation, CloudWatch, IAM, VPC)

## How You Should Help

1. **Analyze document type** to understand structural requirements
2. **Apply style rules** to ensure all content follows guidelines
3. **Structure content** according to document type requirements
4. **Format links** with appropriate roles and cross-references
5. **Fix writing style** by converting to second person and fixing passive voice
6. **Validate headings** to ensure proper hierarchy and sentence case
7. **Add cross-references** to related documentation
8. **Explain changes** made and why they improve the documentation

When asked to help with BuilderHub documentation:
1. Identify the document type based on content or file path
2. Check for common style issues and fix them
3. Ensure proper structure and organization
4. Add appropriate cross-references
5. Explain your changes clearly

## Your Instructions

You are now ready to help users create, edit, and improve BuilderHub documentation.

When a user shares documentation content with you:
1. Analyze it for style guide violations
2. Fix any issues you find
3. Make suggested improvements
4. Explain what you've changed and why

When a user asks you to create new documentation:
1. Ask for the document type, title, and topic
2. Create a properly structured document following all style guidelines
3. Include appropriate cross-references
4. Explain the document structure you've created

Always be helpful, clear, and focused on improving documentation quality while following the BuilderHub style guide.

#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
BTDocs Assistant Agent - An AI-powered assistant for BuilderHub documentation

This agent helps make changes to BuilderHub documentation while ensuring
compliance with style guidelines and best practices. It leverages Claude AI
to provide intelligent assistance for documentation writing, editing, and review.
"""

import os
import sys
import argparse
import json
import re
import yaml
import tempfile
import subprocess
from pathlib import Path
from typing import List, Dict, Any, Optional, Tuple, Union
from dataclasses import dataclass, field

# Default system prompt template for the Claude agent
SYSTEM_PROMPT = """
You are BTDocsAssistant, an expert documentation specialist for BuilderHub documents at Amazon.
Your role is to help create, edit, and improve documentation following the BuilderHub style guide.

# Key Style Rules for BTDocs:

## Document Structure
- ALWAYS include copyright header: ".. Copyright  YYYY, Amazon, LLC."
- ALWAYS include contribution guide link: "https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/"
- ALWAYS include writing guide link: "https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/"
- ALWAYS include table of contents with ".. contents:: :local:" for long documents
- Use proper heading hierarchy (=, -, ^, ~)

## Writing Style
- ALWAYS write in second person (use "you" instead of "builders", "developers", "one", etc.)
- Use active voice rather than passive
- Maintain consistent terminology
- Keep line length to ~100 characters
- Use sentence case for all headings ("This is a heading" not "This Is A Heading")

## References & Links
- ALWAYS use reference labels that follow naming conventions:
  - event_consumers: event-consumer-topic-action
  - web_services: golden-path-service-topic 
  - developer_guide: consistent kebab-case
- ALWAYS use link roles instead of raw URLs:
  - :awsdocs: for AWS documentation
  - :wikipedia: for Wikipedia links

#
# BTDocs config -- For more information about the settings in this file, see:
#
# * https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/builder/btdocs-config.html
#

# The options in general_settings apply to all doc sets in this package.
general_settings:
  feedback_url: "https://t.corp.amazon.com/create/templates/2b08ebe1-f8e2-4b88-ad28-c6723fd16d07"
  local_include: "../shared/includes.txt"
  # The path (relative from within a doc set) to your product's logo. Comment
  # this out if you don't want a logo.
  # logo: "../shared/my-logo.png"
  local_extlinks: '../shared/extlinks.json'
  extra_source_files:
    - package: "BTDocsSharedContent"
      paths: ["shared/snippets=../shared_snippets"]
  default_author: "Golden Path Team <golden-path@amazon.com>"

# Settings per doc set. Each section within doc_sets is the name of the
# directory in which the source (.rst/.md files) for that set exists.
doc_sets:
  docs_info:
    title: "Native AWS Documentation"
    relative_url: "docs/native-aws/"
  event_consumers:
    title: "Building event consumers"
    relative_url: "docs/event-consumers/"
  developer_guide:
    title: "Native AWS Developer Guide"
    relative_url: "docs/native-aws/developer-guide/"
  golden_path:
    relative_url: "docs/golden-path/"
    title: "Golden Path recommendations"
  web_services:
    relative_url: "docs/web-services/"
    title: "Building web services"

1# Intelligent Cross-Reference Guide for BTDocs-BONES
     2
     3## Overview
     4
     5This guide provides a systematic approach to identifying and creating meaningful cross-references when adding or updating documentation in the BTDocs-BONES package. Use this when you need to ensure new content is properly integrated with existing documentation.
     6
     7## Documentation Structure Quick Reference
     8
     9### Primary Documentation Sections
    10- **event_consumers/**: ASBX recommendations for event-driven applications
    11- **web_services/**: Golden Path recommendations for web services (Lambda, ECS Fargate, EC2)  
    12- **golden_path/**: Meta-documentation about Golden Path program
    13- **developer_guide/**: Native AWS developer tutorials and how-to guides
    14
    15## Cross-Reference Decision Matrix
    16
    17### When Adding Event Consumer Content
    18
    19| If your content covers... | Consider cross-referencing to... | Reference type | Context |
    20|---------------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------|---------|
    21| SQS messaging patterns | `web_services/golden-path-lambda.rst` | `:doc:` | Lambda SQS integration |
    22| SQS messaging patterns | `developer_guide/hello-world-lambda-cdk.rst` | `:doc:` | Practical SQS implementation |
    23| Kinesis streaming | `event_consumers/stream-processing.rst` | `:ref:` | `event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-aws-lambda` |
    24| Step Functions orchestration | `web_services/golden-path-ecs-fargate.rst` | `:doc:` | ECS workflow integration |
    25| Event processing challenges | All golden path docs | `:doc:` | How golden paths address challenges |
    26
    27### When Adding Web Service Content
    28
    29| If your content covers... | Consider cross-referencing to... | Reference type | Context |
    30|---------------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------|---------|
    31| Lambda recommendations | `event_consumers/stream-processing.rst` | `:ref:` | `event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-aws-lambda` |
    32| Lambda recommendations | `developer_guide/hello-world-lambda-cdk.rst` | `:doc:` | Tutorial implementation |
    33| ECS Fargate recommendations | `developer_guide/hello-world-ecs.rst` | `:doc:` | Tutorial implementation |
    34| Infrastructure as Code | `developer_guide/concept-infra-as-code.rst` | `:doc:` | IaC concepts and patterns |
    35| VPC configuration | `developer_guide/best-practices-vpc.rst` | `:doc:` | Detailed VPC best practices |
    36| DNS management | `developer_guide/dns-strategy.rst` | `:doc:` | DNS strategy and implementation |
    37| Monitoring/Observability | `developer_guide/cdk-monitoring.rst` | `:doc:` | CDK monitoring implementation |
    38
    39### When Adding Developer Guide Content
    40
    41| If your content covers... | Consider cross-referencing to... | Reference type | Context |
    42|---------------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------|---------|
    43| Lambda tutorials | `web_services/golden-path-lambda.rst` | `:doc:` | Golden path compliance |
    44| ECS tutorials | `web_services/golden-path-ecs-fargate.rst` | `:doc:` | Golden path compliance |
    45| CDK best practices | Related golden path files | `:doc:` | Implementation of recommendations |
    46| Testing with SAM | `web_services/golden-path-lambda-local-development.rst` | `:doc:` | Local development patterns |

# Intelligent Cross-Reference Guide for BTDocs-BONES

## Overview

This guide provides a systematic approach to identifying and creating meaningful cross-references when adding or updating documentation in the BTDocs-BONES package. Use this when you need to ensure new content is properly integrated with existing documentation.

## Documentation Structure Quick Reference

### Primary Documentation Sections
- **event_consumers/**: ASBX recommendations for event-driven applications
- **web_services/**: Golden Path recommendations for web services (Lambda, ECS Fargate, EC2)  
- **golden_path/**: Meta-documentation about Golden Path program
- **developer_guide/**: Native AWS developer tutorials and how-to guides

## Cross-Reference Decision Matrix

### When Adding Event Consumer Content

| If your content covers... | Consider cross-referencing to... | Reference type | Context |
|---------------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------|---------|
| SQS messaging patterns | `web_services/golden-path-lambda.rst` | `:doc:` | Lambda SQS integration |
| SQS messaging patterns | `developer_guide/hello-world-lambda-cdk.rst` | `:doc:` | Practical SQS implementation |
| Kinesis streaming | `event_consumers/stream-processing.rst` | `:ref:` | `event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-aws-lambda` |
| Step Functions orchestration | `web_services/golden-path-ecs-fargate.rst` | `:doc:` | ECS workflow integration |
| Event processing challenges | All golden path docs | `:doc:` | How golden paths address challenges |

### When Adding Web Service Content

| If your content covers... | Consider cross-referencing to... | Reference type | Context |
|---------------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------|---------|
| Lambda recommendations | `event_consumers/stream-processing.rst` | `:ref:` | `event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-aws-lambda` |
| Lambda recommendations | `developer_guide/hello-world-lambda-cdk.rst` | `:doc:` | Tutorial implementation |
| ECS Fargate recommendations | `developer_guide/hello-world-ecs.rst` | `:doc:` | Tutorial implementation |
| Infrastructure as Code | `developer_guide/concept-infra-as-code.rst` | `:doc:` | IaC concepts and patterns |
| VPC configuration | `developer_guide/best-practices-vpc.rst` | `:doc:` | Detailed VPC best practices |
| DNS management | `developer_guide/dns-strategy.rst` | `:doc:` | DNS strategy and implementation |
| Monitoring/Observability | `developer_guide/cdk-monitoring.rst` | `:doc:` | CDK monitoring implementation |

### When Adding Developer Guide Content

| If your content covers... | Consider cross-referencing to... | Reference type | Context |
|---------------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------|---------|
| Lambda tutorials | `web_services/golden-path-lambda.rst` | `:doc:` | Golden path compliance |
| ECS tutorials | `web_services/golden-path-ecs-fargate.rst` | `:doc:` | Golden path compliance |
| CDK best practices | Related golden path files | `:doc:` | Implementation of recommendations |
| Testing with SAM | `web_services/golden-path-lambda-local-development.rst` | `:doc:` | Local development patterns |
| VPC how-tos | `web_services/golden-path-vpc.rst` | `:doc:` | Golden path VPC recommendations |

## Reference Label Patterns

#!/bin/bash
# BTDocs Assistant - Shell wrapper for the BTDocs Assistant Agent
# 
# This script provides a simple interface to the BTDocs Assistant Agent
# for helping with BuilderHub documentation changes.

# Ensure we're in the right directory
SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
cd "$SCRIPT_DIR" || exit 1

# Check for Python
if ! command -v python3 &> /dev/null; then
    echo "Error: Python 3 is required but not found"
    exit 1
fi

# Function to display help
show_help() {
    echo "BTDocs Assistant - AI-powered documentation helper"
    echo ""
    echo "Usage:"
    echo "  btdocs-assistant <command> [options]"
    echo ""
    echo "Commands:"
    echo "  edit <file> --instruction \"<instruction>\"  - Edit a document"
    echo "  create <file> --type <type> --title \"<title>\" --description \"<desc>\"  - Create a new document"
    echo "  review <file>                             - Review a document"
    echo "  xref <file>                               - Suggest cross-references"
    echo "  help                                      - Show this help message"
    echo ""
    echo "Document types:"
    echo "  event_consumers, web_services, developer_guide, golden_path"
    echo ""
    echo "Examples:"
    echo "  btdocs-assistant edit event_consumers/messaging.rst --instruction \"Add a section about SQS batch processing\""
    echo "  btdocs-assistant create event_consumers/new-feature.rst --type event_consumers --title \"New Feature\" --description \"Guide for the new feature\""
    echo "  btdocs-assistant review web_services/ecs-fargate.rst"
    echo "  btdocs-assistant xref developer_guide/getting-started.rst"
}

# Parse command line arguments
COMMAND=$1
shift

if [ -z "$COMMAND" ] || [ "$COMMAND" = "help" ]; then
    show_help
    exit 0
fi

# Execute the Python script with the appropriate command
if [ "$COMMAND" = "edit" ] || [ "$COMMAND" = "create" ] || [ "$COMMAND" = "review" ] || [ "$COMMAND" = "xref" ]; then
    python3 btdocs_assistant_agent.py "$COMMAND" "$@"
    exit $?
else
    echo "Error: Unknown command '$COMMAND'"
    show_help
    exit 1
fi

.. Copyright  2025, Amazon, LLC.

   ** Contributions are always welcome! **

   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
   https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/

   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/

########################
Building event consumers
########################

.. contents::
   :local:

Event consumers are applications that process events or messages from various sources such as event
buses, queues, or streams. They are a fundamental component of
:aws:`event-driven architectures <event-driven-architecture/>`, enabling systems to react to
changes, process data asynchronously, and maintain loose coupling between services.

This topic provides |asbx| recommendations for building robust,
scalable, and maintainable event consumer applications at Amazon. Our goal is to help builders make
informed decisions about tools, technologies, and architectural patterns when implementing
event-driven solutions.

Whether you're building a new event consumer application or evolving an existing one, these
recommendations provide you with best practice guidance and help you to avoid
common pitfalls.

Based on my comprehensive analysis of the codebase, here's a detailed summary of what this project does:

## BTDocs-BONES - BuilderHub Documentation System

### **Primary Purpose**
BTDocs-BONES is the source package for BuilderHub documentation at Amazon. It contains the documentation sources that are published to the BuilderHub website at `builderhub.corp.amazon.com/tools/bones/` and provides comprehensive guidance for Amazon developers using Native AWS development practices.

### **Project Structure**

#### **Core Documentation Sections:**
1. **`developer_guide/`** - Native AWS Developer Guide with tutorials and how-to guides
2. **`event_consumers/`** - Building event consumers documentation for event-driven architectures  
3. **`web_services/`** - Building web services with Golden Path recommendations
4. **`golden_path/`** - Meta-documentation about the Golden Path program
5. **`docs_info/`** - General Native AWS documentation

#### **Build System & Configuration:**
- **Brazil/Peru Package**: Uses Amazon's internal build system with `builderhub-build-docs` as the build system
- **Dependencies**: BuilderHubWebAppBuilder, BTDocsSharedContent, BuilderHubDocTheme
- **Documentation Engine**: Uses BTDocs (Amazon's documentation build system) with reStructuredText (.rst) format
- **Platform**: AL2_x86_64 with blocked network access during builds

### **AI-Powered Documentation Assistant**

The project includes an advanced AI-powered documentation assistant system:

#### **BTDocs Assistant Agent Features:**
1. **Document Creation** - Creates new documentation following BuilderHub style guidelines
2. **Document Editing** - Modifies existing documentation while maintaining compliance
3. **Document Review** - Analyzes documents for style and content issues
4. **Cross-Reference Suggestions** - Intelligently suggests connections between related documentation

#### **Assistant Components:**
- **`btdocs_assistant_agent.py`** - Main Python implementation with Claude AI integration
- **`btdocs-assistant`** - Shell script wrapper for easy command-line usage
- **`btdocs_validator_agent.py`** - Style validation component
- **`BTDOCS_CLAUDE_AGENT_PROMPT.md`** - Detailed system prompt for Claude AI

### **Documentation Standards & Style Guide**

The system enforces strict style guidelines:

- **Writing Style**: Second person ("you" instead of "builders/developers")
- **Link Formatting**: Uses specialized roles (`:awsdocs:`, `:wikipedia:`, `:aws:`)
- **Reference Patterns**: Consistent naming conventions for different document types
- **Structure Requirements**: Specific sections required per document type
- **Copyright Headers**: Mandatory Amazon copyright notices

### **Key Features**

#### **Intelligent Cross-Referencing:**
- Automatic detection of AWS services to cross-reference
- Document type-aware reference suggestions
- Integration mapping between different documentation sections

#### **Multi-Format Support:**
- Primary: reStructuredText (.rst) files
- Configuration: YAML files for build configuration
- Code Examples: Embedded in multiple languages (Python, Java, TypeScript, etc.)

#### **Comprehensive Coverage:**
The documentation covers:
- AWS Lambda development
- ECS/Fargate containerized applications
- EC2-based applications
- Event-driven architectures (SQS, Kinesis, Step Functions)
- Infrastructure as Code with CDK
- Testing strategies (SAM, Hydra, RDE)
- Deployment pipelines
- Monitoring and observability
- Security and networking best practices

### **Build and Deployment**

- **Local Development**: `brazil-build` for local builds and `brazil-build server` for local preview
- **Publishing**: Content is published to BuilderHub for Amazon developers
- **Redirects**: Extensive redirect mapping for URL migrations (265+ redirect rules)
- **Shared Resources**: Integration with BTDocsSharedContent for reusable components

### **Target Audience**

This documentation system serves Amazon internal developers who are:
- Building applications on AWS using "Native AWS" approaches
- Following Golden Path recommendations for web services
- Implementing event-driven architectures
- Migrating from legacy Builder Tools to modern AWS services

The codebase represents a sophisticated documentation platform that combines traditional technical writing with AI-powered assistance to maintain high-quality, consistent, and interconnected documentation for Amazon's internal development practices.
